area_name: Other Side of the River Wall

content.description: Slab problem using the crack to the left and several holds to the right.
content.location: Start low with left hand on the crack and right hand on a little light gray ledge. Climb up the slab, staying right of the crack the whole way.

content.description: Nice slab line with some seams. There were a lot of annoying bugs around when ​​​​​I was there.
content.location: Start on the lower horizontal seam and go straight up.

content.description: Nice slab problem with an opposition start into compression. The names of these two problems are from a silly conversation I had about types of pastes to eat. "Protein Paste (protein powder, peanut butter, honey, and water) is good paste; Caulk is bad paste."
content.location: Start stemming at the bottom and go up and to the right to use both corners as compression.

content.description: Short slab up to a dirty ledge and a mossy crack to the very top.
content.location: Start on the left edge and go up and to the right. From the ledge, follow the crack and top out. Don't use the wall left of the start.

content.description: A very mossy climb climbing out from the little overhang up to the ledge and up the mossy crack. Named after the mothball fleet in the bay area.
content.location: Start with a left pinch and big right sidepull edge. Climb right and onto the ledge. Follow the crack to the top.

content.description: Little seam with interesting moves that are worth trying despite the bushy landing. Some finger-jam-able opposing edges and a mono pocket (two finger jam if reachable) lead to a big downpull edge before the topout.
content.location:
Start by standing up on the little ledge. Follow the seam straight up.

These problems are past the paste problems and past the very low angle scrambling area. They are also right next to the Lowball Boulder. Watch out for possible wasps.

content.description: Easy slab problem going up the seam.
content.location:
Start on the low edge and big foothold. Climb up, following the vertical seam.

These problems are past the paste problems and past the very low angle scrambling area. They are also right next to the Lowball Boulder. Watch out for possible wasps.

content.description: Easy slab climb up the face.
content.location:
Start on the low edge and big foothold. Climb up the face between the crack and seam, using neither.

These problems are past the paste problems and past the very low angle scrambling area. They are also right next to the Lowball Boulder. Watch out for possible wasps.

content.description: Easy slab problem using the left seam and right crack. Right crack might still have ants in it.
content.location:
Start on two sidepulls and climb up between the seam and crack.

These problems are past the paste problems and past the very low angle scrambling area. They are also right next to the Lowball Boulder. Watch out for possible wasps nearby.

content.description: Easy low-angle slab with a crack partway up.
content.location:
Start on a low edge and big foothold. Climb up left into the crack to the top.

These problems are past the paste problems and past the very low angle scrambling area. They are also right next to the Lowball Boulder. Watch out for possible wasps.

content.description: Nice slab problem centered around an undercling and some good slopers. Crack to the left and the edges to the right are off.
content.location: Start on the little light gray ledge and balance up to the undercling. Climb to the right a bit to step directly over the undercling and top out.

content.description: Easy line going left of the bulge. Watch out for the large branches at the beginning.
content.location: Start on the large edge and go up to the left.

content.description: Very easy low angle slab.
content.location: Start on the first sidepull and go straight up.

content.description: Tall line going up to the offwidth crack to the right. Be careful as this line goes directly above a dead tree with upward-facing branches.
content.location: Start on the big edge and go right into the offwidth.

content.description: Interesting slab line with every hold, including footholds, much bigger than the starting handholds.
content.location: Start on the tiny left hand crimp and slopey right hand edge. Go up to the big jug and finish relatively straight up.

climbs.name: Crack and Seam Make a Great Team

content.description: A nice slab line with a crack and seam side by side.
content.location: Start just under the first bush and go straight up.

content.description: Tricky slab problem with cool moves. The crux is trusting the smear to stand up and go right. The names of these two problems are from a silly conversation I had about types of pastes to eat. "Protein Paste (protein powder, peanut butter, honey, and water) is good paste; Caulk is bad paste."
content.location: Start on the downpull jug and go up and right, not turning the corner until stood up on the smeary slab. Topout just right of the corner.

content.description:
An eliminate of

Crack and Seam Make a Great Team

​​​​with the crack off-route.
content.location: Start on the seam under the first bush and go straight up without using the crack.

content.description: Short boulder onto the ledge and easy topout up the mossy crack. Mind the dead branches.
content.location: Start on a left sidepull edge and right pinch. Go straight up to the ledge and follow the mossy crack to the top.

content.description: Nice easy crack with some good jamming spots. There were too many ants before, so I came back and climbed it later.
content.location:
Start with your hands about chest height in the crack and follow it to the top.

These problems are past the paste problems and past the very low angle scrambling area. They are also right next to the Lowball Boulder. Watch out for possible wasps.

pathTokens: Other Side of the River Wall
